reason: FALSE IMPLICIT CLAIM THAT SUSY FAILS AT ROOT OF UNITY: The root node restricts its one-parameter family to 'q > 0 real' for the SUSY quantum mechanical models, and then introduces Part III (q = root of unity) as a separate regime. This framing, combined with child nodes 1.4 section (C) and 1.4.3, implies that the SUSY structure is lost at root of unity. This is MATHEMATICALLY FALSE. For ANY operator Q on a Hilbert space, {Q, Q^dagger} >= 0 is a tautological consequence of the definition of the adjoint: <v|{Q,Q^dag}|v> = ||Q^dag v||^2 + ||Qv||^2 >= 0. This holds regardless of whether Q has real or complex matrix elements, and regardless of q. The root node inherits the critical error from nodes 1.4 (challenge ch-4dfe459e979) and 1.4.3 (challenges ch-fae7c260267 and ch-1056031c664). Specifically: (1) Node 1.4.3 claims {Q_q, Q_q^dagger} can have negative eigenvalues at root of unity -- provably false. (2) Node 1.4.3 provides a purported 'explicit example' (j=1, q=exp(2*pi*i/5)) of negative eigenvalues -- numerically verified false. (3) Node 1.4 concludes the root-of-unity regime 'loses the SUSY quantum mechanical interpretation' -- unfounded. The root node's restriction to 'q > 0 real' for SUSY models is unnecessarily restrictive. The SUSY algebra (Q^2 = 0, H = {Q,Q^dag} >= 0) extends to root of unity provided the q-3j symbols are well-defined (i.e., j satisfies the admissibility constraint j <= (r-2)/2). The root node cannot be accepted while it inherits this critical error from its children.
